Award.AwardTitle: Coupling of Sodium and Substrate Fluxes in the Na+/multivitamin Transporter

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: Despite our increasing knowledge of the structures of sodium-coupled membrane transport proteins, understanding the mechanism by which the energy of the transmembrane electrochemical sodium ion gradient is translated into the coupled transport of other molecules across the membrane is still a major challenge. This project will test the central hypothesis that the allosteric interaction of two substrate binding sites in the sodium/multivitamin transporter is required for coupled transport. The results of this project are expected to lead to a novel paradigm for the mechanism of ion-gradient coupled membrane transport, a central feature in the biology of all living systems. Broader Impacts. This project integrates teaching in molecular biological and membrane biochemical/biophysical techniques within its overall scientific objectives through hands-on education of the next generation of scientists (i.e., graduate and undergraduate students, pre-college students, and K-12 science teachers). Special consideration will be given to broadening the participation of women and under-represented groups, and the PI?s outreach activities include the international exchange of undergraduate and graduate students with Spain and Germany.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the molecular events that regulate the sodium ion (Na+)-dependent uptake of the essential vitamins biotin (vitamin H) and pantothenic acid (vitamin B5), as well as α-lipoic acid (LA), a potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory agent by the human Na+/multivitamin transporter (hSMVT). The recent progress in transporter fields, due in part to the steadily increasing number of high-resolution crystal structures of Na+-dependent transporters that serve as context and reference for modeling, has led to mechanistic models that ultimately require validation by functional studies. In particular, understanding of how the energy of the transmembrane electrochemical Na+ gradient is transduced into transport work is still a major challenge in the field. Focusing on hSMVT as amenable model system, the PI has taken quantitative steps to address this critical gap in our understanding. By using a combinatory approach that employed functional studies (e.g., electrophysiology, radiotracer flux and binding) of hSMVT in cellular systems and in purified, detergent-solubilized and reconstituted form, the results of this project revealed that hSMVT recognizes only one chiral form of α-lipoic acid (the R-enantiomer, R-LA) as substrate. This finding questions the therapeutic efficiency of racemic mixtures of R-LA and S-LA used as dietary supplements and in clinical applications. Taking advantage of the research team’s achievement to purify hSMVT to apparent homogeneity, a nanotechnology-based radiotracer binding assay was used to show that hSMVT can simultaneously bind two molecules of R-LA. This finding supports previous findings of the PI according to which substrate transport by proteins that are structurally similar to hSMVT involves the allosteric interaction of two substrate binding sites. Direct radiolabeled Na+ binding and flux studies suggest that hSMVT mediates stoichiometrically-coupled Na+ co-transport of biotin, pantothenic acid, and R-LA. Building on the accomplishments of this project, the PI will investigate in further detail the elements of Na+-coupled transport by hSMVT and related proteins to obtain a comprehensive picture of the molecular interplay of this class of proteins and their transported substrates.

Broader Impacts. This project integrated teaching of a wide spectrum of students (i.e., graduate and undergraduate students, and pre-college students) in the basic principles of membrane bioenergetics through hands-on training in molecular biological and membrane biochemical/biophysical techniques within its overall scientific scope on Na+-coupled membrane transport processes. Special consideration was given to broadening the participation of women and under-represented groups in the research activities. The PI continued his fruitful interactions with high schools in Westchester County, e.g., by serving as mentor for aspiring students in context with their original science research projects. Several students participating in the project won prizes at national and international high school science competitions (e.g., the Intel Science Talent Search and the Junior Science and Humanities Symposia). The PI also entered into a direct dialogue with K-12 students, as well as their teachers and parents to share the myriad of exciting discoveries in the field of membrane transport in intelligible form and to increase the scientific literacy of the general public. Furthermore, this project served as platform for the exchange of students and technologies at the international level.
